title: Yul Kwon: “Don't Try to Change Yourself All at Once.” (UPDATE) | People I (Mostly) Admire

rawLines.text: Today's episode is an encore
presentation of a conversation I had
with Yule Quan way back in January 2021,
not long after I started the podcast. It
was such a good conversation that we
turned it into two episodes. The first
time we'd ever done that. Today, we've
condensed those two episodes back into
one, keeping just the very best. I hope
you enjoy it. Ule is an absolutely
amazing human being. Before we jump into
the episode, I have one quick
announcement. Regular listeners will
know that I'm helping launch a radical
new high school this fall on the Arizona
State campus in Tempe. We are in the
process right now of hiring worldclass
teachers. If you know anyone who might
be interested, all the information is
available in the show notes. And to make
it worth your while to pass along that
information, I'm offering $5,000 and a
signed copy of Freconomics as a finders
fee for each teacher we hire who found
out about the job because of the
podcast. So, please spread the word.
I'll be very grateful.
[Music]
My guest today, Ule Kuan, has done a
little bit of everything. He's got a law
degree from Yale, taught courses at the
FBI, hosted television shows on PBS and
CNN, started a frozen yogurt chain, and
held highle jobs at Facebook and Google.
He even won season 13 of the TV show
Survivor. You don't want to tell people
that you're using game theory cuz then
that starts freaking people out, right?
They like, "Oh, no. What's going on?"
Like, "Well, you're manipulating me."
Welcome to People I Mostly Admire with
Steve Levit. I first met Ule a few years
back. A mutual friend introduced us
saying Ule was the smartest person she
had ever met. We said hello. You'll
asked me what I was working on and I
told him about a new project using GPS
technology in the criminal justice
system. Just so happened that Ule had
worked for 2 years on GPS and he gave me
great advice that really shaped that
project. Then he asked me what else was
I working on and I mentioned another
project. Well, Ule just happened to know
exactly the right person to help me get
that project implemented. A third
project, Ule had thought about that
issue as well and he had three great
reasons why the project was going to
fail. He convinced me to drop the
project. So since then, I make it a
point to run all my new projects past
Ule. Ule, it's so great to have you here
with us today. You were a high achieving
teen, validictorian in high school, a
varsity water polo, and track and field
athlete before going on to Stanford
where you graduated five beta kappa, a
highly selective honor society. It
sounds like things came pretty easy to
you early in life. Yeah, I guess if you
look on paper, it looks like I did lots
of good stuff, but you know, the reality
is that I felt like certainly my
childhood was a struggle. My parents
immigrated here from South Korea back in
1970. They didn't have a lot of money. I
think my dad had something like $200 in
his pockets. And I grew up being a very
introverted, shy kid. But I think as I
grew older, they kind of evolved into
some more significant liabilities. I
really struggled with social anxiety for
most of my life and also was bullied
quite a bit when I was a child and I
think that led to some long-term
challenges for me. And so that doesn't
sound like the ingredients for a kid who
was going to be five beta cap at
Stanford. Did something happened along
the way? What happened to turn you into
such an achiever?
You know, honestly, I think a lot of it
was I just wanted to be normal growing
up. I had a lot of anxiety. I had pretty
severe OCD to the point where I would
wash my hands like 20 times a day. I had
this obsession with even numbers, you
know. And I think the thing that
probably was the most debilitating was
when I was in elementary school, a lot
of the older kids would pick on some of
the younger kids. And it got to the
point where they would hide in the
bathroom. And when one of the younger
kids would come in, they would try to
grab the kid and hold him against the
wall while the other boys would take
turns urinating on them. And you know,
that was just like a crazy traumatic
thing. In my case, I never got caught,
but it instilled in me this deep fear
and anxiety around going to the
bathroom. And it developed into this
thing called paruresis, which is an
inability to relax enough to go to the
bathroom around other people. It doesn't
sound like much, but the practical
constraints are pretty immense. It
basically meant that I couldn't go to
parties or ball games or to the mall or
to movies or anything where I didn't
know that I would be able to access a
private bathroom. I would spend 50% of
my day worrying about this. And so all
these different things, all these
different anxieties that I had really, I
think, limited my ability to function
normally and to really have a happy life
as a kid. I wish I had the courage to
open up and ask for help, but I didn't
know how. Especially in the Asian
community, things like mental health and
psychological well-being, those are
taboo subjects and they're often seen as
a source of embarrassment for the
family. So, I think for me, just more
out of desperation than anything else, I
thought about how my life would unfold.
And I realized that if I didn't start
changing now, then it wouldn't lead to a
happy ending. At that point, I just
really started thinking like, what can I
do? How can I change myself? like what
are the things I can put into place now?
And it was such a daunting challenge,
but I tried to tell myself I didn't have
to change overnight. Just break things
down into manageable chunks. Like what
can I do today? What can I do tomorrow
just to push myself a little bit outside
my comfort zone. So, for example, I told
myself, okay, today in school, I'm going
to raise my hand in class. You know,
something I'd never done before. It just
scare the crap out of me. Or today I'm
going to sit next to someone I don't
know and say hi. And I didn't always do
it and it didn't always end up having a
good outcome. But I generally found that
like a lot of times if you try, you
know, good things come out of it. And
even if they don't, it's not the end of
the world. I did some other things, too.
I knew that it's really hard to change
yourself just through sheer willpower.
You know, it's often easier to change
when you change the environment. So, I
started doing things like signing up for
a drama class, which would have never
occurred to me when I was younger. But,
you know, if you're in drama class,
everyone's kind of scared. First, let me
say I feel tremendous empathy for little
Ule and the suffering you're going
through. It sounds awful. How old were
you when you came to this realization
that these incremental changes could
transform your life? I think it was
sometime in middle school. I think that
was the time where I really remember
having this conscious decision that I
wanted to not be like in 5 years or in
30 years. I didn't want to be this
person that I was. You know what's
interesting about that, Ule, is that I
did something very similar. It was in
maybe 8th grade. I also decided that I
despised the person that I was.
Interestingly for me, I had a sister,
Linda, who was 5 years older than me and
I was able to turn to her and she was an
incredibly talented and creative person
and I said to her, I just want to remake
myself. I want to be a different person.
She was exactly the type of person who
took that kind of challenge as her
ultimate being. So, she invested
incredibly heavily in helping me to
transform who I was. It's interesting. I
think my path was simpler. I didn't have
as many of the really hard built-in
challenges that you had. Do you have any
recollection of how it was you actually
committed yourself to stay on this
incredibly difficult path? You know,
it's really interesting that you raise a
point about your older sister. I
actually had a similar conversation with
my brother that was for me pretty
pivotal and I think addresses your
point. My brother was someone who had
built this confidence that I felt like I
was always lacking growing up. My
brother was very angry at times. He
basically explained that a lot of his
anger came from fear and insecurity. He
basically decided look if I don't have
confidence maybe the thing I can try is
to pretend to be confident. And he found
that the more he acted confident the
more positive reactions he would get
from other people. and it would actually
in turn build real confidence. And I
think that's the thing that allowed me
to stay committed to this program. I saw
that over time it was having real
impact. It's not that people are
infinitely plastic. It's not like you
can completely change fundamentally who
you are, but it is more flexible than I
think people often think. You're
essentially talking about the idea fake
it till you make it. And research has
actually shown that this works, that
just acting extroverted can lead to a
higher well-being. So knowing what you
know now, do you have advice for a kid
or even an adult who's struggling with
these kinds of issues? Yeah, totally.
You know, eventually went into therapy
and I found that to be enormously useful
and I just wish I had found that sooner.
Beyond that, I think the things that I
did for myself are things that are still
applicable, which is don't try to change
yourself all at once. Like there is a
possibility of change. I know because I
went through that process, too. The
important thing is that you just keep on
doing it. So part of your strategy of
self-improvement is to put yourself in
difficult
situations. What would you say the most
difficult situation you ever managed to
put yourself into was? Once I had gotten
into college, I eventually got to a
point where I felt like I had sort of
plateaued. I was thinking like, what is
the hardest thing I could do? And then
sort of fortuitously, I opened my
mailbox and I got this flyer saying,
"Hey, join the Marine Corps. Boot camp
for the Marine Corps is super hard." And
even within the Marine Corps, the really
hard thing was called Officer Candace
School. For OCS, not only do you have to
go through a lot of the hard emotional
challenges of boot camp, but you also
are really stressed physically because
the Marine Corps really believes that
officers have to set an example for the
people that they're leading. So, I
applied, I got in, and oh my god, that
was
like that was crazy. I had many nights
when I was weeping in bed thinking, "Oh
my god, what did I get myself into?"
Yeah. I'm really curious to hear. So,
what do they do to you? And how did you
respond? Oh, man. It was unlike anything
I'd ever experienced before. You know,
you go there and soon as you get off the
bus, they're just screaming at you.
You're like disoriented. You have no
idea what's going on. And the whole
thing is kind of like that. I mean, the
basic idea is that they're trying to
break down any sense of ego or
selfidentity and eventually try to build
you back up into a unit. And that
breaking down part was just incredibly
painful. I also got a lot of crap from
the other guys for, you know, being too
well educated. Like they thought I was
kind of weak and they were wondering
what I was doing there. The other thing,
too, was I was the only Asian-American
in my platoon. So, I also felt sort of
marginalized for that perspective. But
again, I for me, it's just one of those
things like I knew that if I dropped
out, this would eat at me. There was
this one incident that actually helped
me figure it out. You sometimes do
sentry duty, so you're essentially
standing guard. What you're supposed to
do when you see a superior officer is
that you're supposed to stand up
straight, you know, kind of stick your
chest out and you salute them. And in my
case, I was stressed out. I was tired. I
was kind of scared. And then the
commander of the base comes walking by.
The major, he's like the big head honcho
for the whole thing. And when I saw him,
I just totally freaked out. I was like,
"Oh." And so I immediately just bowed to
him. Like I literally bowed to this guy.
And he stops in his tracks and he looks
at me. He goes,
"Canon, did you just bow to me?" And I'm
like, "Uh, yes, sir. This candidate did
bow to you, sir." He's like, "Why the
hell did you do that?" I'm like, "Uh,
this candidate does not know why this
candidate bowed to the officer." Sir,
all right, you idiot. Give me 100
push-ups. I'm like, so I'm doing like
these push-ups and I go one, two, and
I'm in my head, I'm just like, what
happened to me? No one ever taught me to
bow to a super officer. and I'm like at
push-up number 40 or something. This
light bulb goes off in my head. I was
raised in a very different environment.
I I grew up as part of a very
traditional Asian family. And in Korean
culture, if you're talking to a superior
or like your father, the proper posture
is one of difference. You you basically
lower your head, you bow your shoulders,
you look kind of down, and if you ask a
question, you speak in a very soft
voice. And what I realized is that I'd
been raised in this tradition, this
these set of cultural norms all of my
life. And under conditions of stress, I
automatically resorted to these
instinctual behaviors. So, you know, in
this case, when I was tired, stressed
out, and I saw this really high level
officer coming at me, I just bowed
because that was just a thing I'd been
taught to do ever since I was a child.
And so I realized, hey, you know, all
the criticism that people had of me that
I was lacking discipline, you know, at
the time it didn't make sense to me
because I knew I was working my butt
off. What I realized is that it's not a
lack of discipline per se. It's just
that these people didn't understand the
cultural norms that I grew up with. And
they interpreted that as a lack of
discipline. So I realized, hey, you know
what? I have to change my behavior. I
have to learn the right mode of
interacting and overcome these natural
instincts that I have. And so from that
point on, it really just locked in for
me. Like I started I started being an
And I just realized like I just
had to harden up and just mimic the
behaviors of the people around me and
learn to project myself. I started
becoming more aware of the way that
people perceived me and the mannerisms
that I had that would often cause people
to jump to conclusions about who I was
and what kind of person I was. And that
itself was such a valuable insight
because it made me learn how to change
myself in order to be successful across
different environments.
I think this next question I'm going to
ask you is going to be the hardest
question that I ask. So, after you
graduated from law school, can you just
list off in order the set of
organizations you've worked for over the
last 20 years? Okay, let's see. After
law school, I went to work at a law firm
in Silicon Valley. Then I worked uh for
Joe Lieberman uh in DC after 9/11. Then
I worked at another law firm. Then I
went to clerk for a judge uh in New York
on the second circuit. Then I went to
work at Mackenzie as a management
consultant. And then I went to Google
for a hot second. Then I went on
Survivor. Then after Survivor, I did a
lot of nonprofit work. I also started a
frozen yogurt chain. Did that for a few
years. And then I went back to DC to
work at the Federal Communications
Commission. Then I left to host a
miniseries on PBS on technology. At one
point I worked as an agent instructor at
the FBI academy. I went to work at
Facebook. I was there for about 5 and a
half years and then I left to go back to
Google where I've been for the last two
and a half years. So unlike most people,
you seem to be quite good at quitting
something when it's not right for you
and finding something better. Yes, I'm a
quitter. That's exactly right.
Do you have any advice for folks who are
stuck? What are your strategies when
you're feeling stuck?
I guess the fact that I've had so many
different jobs is partly intentional and
partly coincidence. I've always felt the
need to challenge myself and push myself
because I'm naturally a very timid and
anxious person and left to my own
devices. I have a tendency to collapse
into myself. So I think whenever I feel
a little bit too comfortable, I know
it's time for me to start pushing myself
again. The other thing in terms of my
career, I've always tried to find the
holy grail, the one job that gave me
everything I was looking for. job
satisfaction challenged me working with
great people, financial security,
working at a place where I believe in
the mission. And I've generally been
pretty disappointed. And so what I
concluded at some point in my career was
what if I took kind of a longerterm
view, a portfolio theory of my career so
that over time and over the cumulative
experiences I will have gotten all the
things that I'm looking for. So you know
at different points in my career I've
optimized for different things. I think
taking that view has been really helpful
for me and taking that approach has for
the most part has given me a pretty high
level of career satisfaction that I
think I otherwise wouldn't have had. So
you've made a lot of changes in your
life. So I'm curious, do you have more
regrets about the changes you have made
or about the changes that you never made
but you wish you had? I would probably
say that maybe I switched too many
times. Like I generally think that it's
good to challenge yourself and to put
yourself into different environments
that will force you to grow and develop
new skill sets. As I've gotten older
though, I generally feel like I don't
know a lot about any one thing, but I
know a little bit about a lot of things.
There have been times in my career where
I wish I was the expert in the room cuz
it can be kind of exhausting ramping up
from scratch. So, I think there's
probably a happy medium and a balance to
be found. One thing that I've found to
be helpful as I'm thinking through my
choices in life and my career, I do this
thought experiment. I'll look back and
see how I've changed over the last, say,
four years. And I'll put myself back
into the shoes of me of four years ago.
And I'll ask myself, if the ule of four
years ago could look ahead into the
future and see me as I am today, what
would that person think? And would I be
happy with that?
[Music]
We'll be right back with more of my
conversation with Yul Quan after this
short
[Music]
break. So you it's December
2005. You've cycled through I don't know
7 12 jobs already since you graduated
from law school. you get a phone call or
knock on the door. Who is it and what
happens? My friend had met a casting
agent for a reality show, Survivor. And
I talked to the casting agent and they
basically told me, "Listen, we've
interviewed thousands of people, but we
want to interview you. Can you come down
to LA this weekend and go through the
final casting call?" And for lots of
different reasons, I thought, "Yeah, why
not? Why don't I go forward with this?"
Why would they want you? You're nerdy
guy doing consulting. Yeah, I had no
idea at the time. As I found out later
on once the game actually started, the
producers had this kind of crazy idea to
divide the tribes based on race. So
essentially, they were going to have a
race war. And for this, they were
looking to create a tribe of Caucasian
people, African-American people,
Latinos, and Asians. And back then, you
just didn't get a lot of Asian people
playing to be on reality shows. I've
always been curious, how hard is it on
Survivor? Walk us through the process of
how you get from the door of the plane
to in your case one of the Cook Islands
and then can you tell us how hard it is
physically and and what makes it not so
hard or really hard physically and
emotionally? It's pretty daunting. So,
what happens is you go to LA first and
then you stay in a hotel. You're not
allowed to have any interaction with any
of the other contestants. At some point,
they take your phone away and then you
get onto a plane and you're zipped off
to wherever you need to go. They do some
basic training. They give you some basic
survival skills like don't eat this fish
that's poisonous. And then they'll start
the game. And then for my season back
then, they had a marooning. We had to
get into a small boat that was blacked
out. And then we're just waiting in the
ocean for hours. And you're incredibly
like claustrophobic. I get terribly
seasick sitting there. I was had a panic
attack because I was like not feeling
well. You know, I still had the shy
bladder syndrome, the paresis. So, you
know, I I couldn't go pee and I just
felt like my bladder was going to
explode. I think we're at that point in
time in the middle of a storm and so the
seas were really rough and we're all
throwing up left and right. We're just
like, it was so bad. And then finally,
finally, finally, finally, the game
starts. The cameras roll. Jeff probes,
the host, comes out and he says, "All
right, you have like two minutes to grab
as many suppliers on the ship and get
off." And then just all panonian breaks
loose. Like, you're grabbing all the
things that you can, trying to throw
them overboard onto these rafts that
you're supposed to get onto with as much
gear as you can collect. And by this
time, we had kind of figured out we're
divided into racial tribes. So, I was,
you know, with my Asian tribe on this
boat along with all the other tribes
fighting for resources. And there's this
one guy named Cowboy who's like this
older gentleman. He was essentially cast
and fit another stereotype. I was the
Asian nerd and then he was sort of like
the I don't know the crazy kung fu
master type person. So cowboy runs up to
me and this is the first time we've been
able to talk to each other. So he's
like, "You e you go get that chicken."
I'm like, "What are you talking about?
What chicken?" And it turns out there
was a chicken that had been on the ship
that had flown off the ship and was like
bombing around in the ocean. And you
know, in my kind of confused state, I
didn't think anything of it. I was like,
"Okay." I jumped off the ship into the
water. And then as soon as I hit the
water, I had this like moment of
clarity. I'm like, "What the am I doing?
Why did I just jump off the ship? And
how am I going to get back on?" Like, I
had no idea. So, you know, I'm now kind
of struggling in these like bobbing
waves. And I look up and I see all these
cameras on me. I'm like, "Oh my god, I'm
going to drown in the ocean. I'm a
survivor." So, I'm like, "All right,
well, I guess I better go get that
chicken." So, then I'm like swimming
back to the ship with this chicken in
one hand. And then, uh, when I get to
the ship, this other guy, cowboy, like
reached down and takes the chicken. And
I spent most of the time that everyone
was getting resources, slowly crawling
my way up the side of the ship. And by
the time I got back on, I was completely
exhausted. I couldn't move. And then as
soon as I got on, Jeff Pro says, "All
right, time to get off. Get off the
ship. Everyone has to get off the ship."
And I'm like, "Oh no."
Oh, this is terrible. So, at that point
in time, I went looking for the chicken
and I see someone from the white tribe
had taken my chicken. I was running away
with my chicken and it just occurred to
me like that entire ordeal was
completely for not. That was probably
the closest I got to quitting cuz I was
so exhausted and I just did not feel
physically or mentally well uh or
emotionally and I was like, I don't
think I can hack it. But again, going on
survivor itself was another
instantiation of this kind of lifelong
commitment I've had to putting myself
into situations that made me
uncomfortable. It was the most
frightening thing I could possibly
imagine being exposed in front of
millions of people. So, at that moment,
I said, I have to do this. Like, if I
quit now, I'm going to revert back to my
old ways cuz I have lost confidence in
myself. So, I just kept through it. And
fortunately, that was the worst probably
day I've had. There are other lots of
bad days. I mean, the reality of being
on Survivor is it really sucks. There's
no food, there's no bathrooms, there's
no soap. It was pretty rough. And how
many calories do you think you consumed
on average on a day on Survivor? Uh,
man, I don't know. Not a lot. Uh, that
season they did not give us any food. In
subsequent seasons, they at least give
you a small a lotment of rice just to
let you subsist. Uh, but back then I
think they were saying, you know,
there's enough natural food out there
that if you can't figure it out, then
you probably don't deserve to be here.
So, occasionally we would get some fish.
For the most part, we lived off of
coconuts and that was pretty much it.
What was your plan as you started the
game? I had a pretty good sense of how
you should play the game. So, you know,
one thing that you always see people
doing over and over again is acting like
a jerk. It just happens every season and
you keep thinking to yourself like why
do these people act like idiots? I think
the answer to that as I found out is
that if you're in an environment where
you're miserable and it's just arduous
and you're dirty and you're scratching
all these bites, it's hard to kind of
keep a lid on your emotions. But that's
one obvious thing. Just generally be a
pleasant person. Another lesson learned
at a high level is like you don't want
to be too much of a leader. You don't
want to be the person who's telling
people what to do because generally
people don't like being told what to do
and if you happen to be a good leader
then you're a potential threat, right?
At the same time, you can't go too far
under the radar. So, it's that fine line
and at the same time pulling enough
moves that are subtle and in the
background but are visible enough that
when you make your case to the jury at
the very end, you can build a compelling
case. Did you have a particular set of
strategies in mind as you launched into
the show? Yeah. So from a game theory
perspective, I was always a fan of
Robert Axelrod's work around the uh
evolution of cooperation. He was a
political scientist who's really
interested in trying to figure out what
is the optimal strategy for praying
prisoners dilemma. So for people who
don't know what we mean by the prisoners
dilemma, let me just say it's a
situation in which they're two players
and if they can cooperate, they'll both
be better off. But the private
incentives are such that they want to
cheat on the other person and in the end
that typically leaves both of them worse
off. Yeah. So one thing he did back I
think around 1980 was to host a
tournament where he invited some of the
most prominent researchers, economists,
political scientists, computer
scientists to submit a strategy for
playing iterated prisoners dilemma in
the form of a computer program. So he
set up a tournament where all of these
programs would essentially compete
against each other in a roundrobin
tournament of iterated prisoners
dilemma. And each time they played
against each other, it would be like
something like 200 rounds. There were
lots of different strategies that were
submitted. Some were pretty complicated.
The thing that ended up winning was one
of the simplest programs. I think it
only had something like four lines of
code and it was submitted by this
mathematical psychologist named Anatl
Rapaort. His strategy was something
called tit fortat. It starts off
cooperating. It starts off being nice
and then it just copies whatever the
other guy did the last time. So if the
other program cooperated then the next
time tit for tat would like okay I'm
going to cooperate too. If the other
program backstabs then tit fortat's like
okay I'm going to backstab you I'm going
to get retribution but then if the other
program starts cooperating again then
tit fortat would cooperate. So super
super easy program and tit fortat ended
up getting more points over the course
of the tournament than any other program
by a wide margin. I teach a class to the
undergrads that is a economics course
for non-econ majors and one of my
lectures is on game theory and in
particular on the prison dilemma and
indeed I try to tell them at the end of
the lecture that tit fortat is a pretty
good strategy for life and basically
says start out being kind and giving
people the benefit of the doubt when
they betray you react fiercely and
punitively and let them know that it's
